output: Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Ciber for the work he has done, because his report addresses many of the concerns expressed here.
These are crucial issues for the entire European Union. They are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be a problem only for the countries of southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections made in the opinion report for which I was rapporteur in the Committee on Agriculture in favor of agricultural activity, highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate prices in raw materials. In this aspect, I also think it is very important to point out the current times so that we keep in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Committee on the Environment also included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action that is also mentioned in the Committee on Agriculture report and which I hope will one day be reflected in concrete actions.

The text that will be put to a vote tomorrow includes, however, a proposal made by the Agriculture Committee to study the establishment of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue to defend the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will propose again to Parliament when the Commission's planned communication on adaptation to climate change is published in the coming months.

I believe that, after the Solidarity Fund was established to mitigate losses caused by climate calamities, it is time for us to consider an instrument that acts beforehand and is intended to finance prevention measures to reduce the environmental and economic cost of these climate disasters.

With this Directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The aim of this Directive is clear: to combat mafias, punish unscrupulous employers and protect exploited immigrants who have no social protection.
We want the unjust poverty wages for immigrants to disappear and, in addition, to spread the average wages, especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and a lot of money circulating in the underground economy.
Precisely in difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity, but with responsibility.
The easy thing would be to give in to the temptation of not trying to tackle the underground economy.
We cannot look the other way and leave some eight million irregular immigrants in a state of defenselessness, with working conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and gentlemen, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions are necessary in the most aggravated cases, which have a deterrent effect on employers.
This will help us reduce the informal economy and cut off the incentive for migration that is generated by the possibility of working irregularly.
It should be clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.

That is why we want to move forward with the global approach and we ask the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Barrot, to present the new blue cards, as soon as possible, for the other employment categories.
Esteemed colleagues, Mrs. Ferrero-Waldner, Mr. Solana, I would first like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work, and as shadow rapporteur for the report on fisheries, I will refer to

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to equip itself with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, the House itself has also shown itself to be cohesive in evaluating and promoting the major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

The efforts of our Group, the Sociala Group, have gone in a dual direction: on the one hand, introducing or reinforcing major issues that are key to us in a transversal manner throughout all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of the

Peace throughout the planet or a commitment to human development. On the other hand, propose elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of fishing compared to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or introduce them as new elements if they were absent.
This way, we have achieved, for example, greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the recently defined Eastern dimension.
We have advocated for greater diversification and greater relevance in relations with Africa, a continent that we often only remember when wars of particular virulence occur, and often not even then.

With regard to Latin America, we have wanted to reflect the current processes of negotiating association agreements, the first of a directional nature that the European Union will conclude in its entire history.

As for the Mediterranean, we have moved away from a reductionist approach that only talks about security, in order to instead include the entire rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained in the Barcelona Process.

As for the amendments for the Po, our Group has not submitted any, believing that this somehow strengthens the balance achieved with the compromises, and therefore, we will oppose most of the amendments so as not to weaken the compromise reached in the Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Mr President, the referendum in Venezuela has ended in a victory for the 'yes' side, elegantly acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that there has been no equality of opportunity in the campaign and that the ruling party has had the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under these conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the good of the country.
It is not with visceral attitudes, disqualifications or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralist and free path.

In that sense, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish Member of the European Parliament and even more so the manner in which the expulsion was carried out. But we call on this House to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visit to third countries that violate the local legislation in force and, even less so, that they insult a head of state, no matter how much this person may be open to criticism.
with these attitudes, we are compromising future missions of the European Parliament to other countries
Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by your electoral power as a member of an international electoral observation group for the referendum held on the 15th.

The European members of that Group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council with an overall positive assessment of the process in terms of its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, it was noted that they came to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, made serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and implied interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation.
Our Parliament should not encourage any kind of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
On the contrary, it would be up to the minister to provide explanations to this House about an action that affects us all.

At this late hour on Monday, the committee will probably have other things to worry about more than this report.
what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a commission report on the implementation of regulation 1206/2001 of the
The Council of 28 May 2001 concerning cooperation between the courts of the Member States in the taking of evidence in civil or commercial matters.

We are in a field that is not truly communitarian; it is an intergovernmental field in which, from the Council, through the Regulation, an attempt has been made to stimulate cooperation between these judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.
That is to say, certain measures have been planned, for example, the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic media, etc. But I recognize that action by the Commission is quite difficult.

I know what the Commission has achieved or plans to achieve, but I think it is quite difficult to achieve it because of the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation represents.

If we are asking judicial authorities to collaborate with each other, we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities who handle 22 different languages with very distinct legal systems, and we are trying to achieve results.
The Commission has found that the results are not good, that there is a huge delay in these cooperation mechanisms and, of course, we do not have the means to do so.
Ideally, we would have the necessary material resources.
For example, what could the Commission do to adopt technological elements for judicial bodies, especially those at a lower level, such as a videoconferencing system?
Videoconferencing may be a utopia for many small courts across the European Union, but it seems to be the only way to do it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European judicial network.
We would have to strengthen this institution so that the judges themselves, through their cooperation systems, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any kind of training for judges is fundamental.
this is something that the commission cannot do on its own either.
But the Commission can indeed encourage the development of this type of training courses in community relations and knowledge of different legal systems.
There is a huge difficulty which is the problem of languages, that is, how can a Spanish judge communicate with a Finnish judge with two such different languages.
Judges cannot be expected to not only have to handle their own law, which is complex enough on its own, but also be required to have knowledge of this type of law.
What can we do from a practical standpoint to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
translation we could make to help them do it

This 2001 regulation is somewhat imprecise and somewhat voluntary, and I'm not sure whether, from a practical standpoint, it can have any consequences or whether it can be used to make progress.
Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, the Erika shipwreck off the French coast, which gave its name to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at preventing and avoiding accidents.

We thought we had already averted the danger, but shortly afterwards the coasts of Galicia were ruined by the oil slick, coming from another accident even worse than the first one, the one involving the ship.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, trying to overcome the many resistances we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals because they considered them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise because, in effect, the cuts proposed by the Council did not prove effective in their initial drafting.

we tested the rules for the introduction of double-hull ships, the European Fund for major oil spills, ports of refuge, and now we review and approve the liability of passenger carriers by sea, the investigation of

maritime accidents, the Community system for monitoring and information on maritime traffic, port State control and, finally, the Regulation and Directive concerning ship inspection and survey organizations.
And it is good and desirable that all this can come into force and be applied by all the Member States in the shortest possible time.
That is why I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term is coming to an end, I am leaving Parliament, and I am leaving with the regret of not having succeeded in making the introduction of existing control systems mandatory.
They are patented to know when and how much bilge and fuel tank waste has been illegally dumped at sea by a particular vessel.
In other words, a kind of black box, speed logs that can be inspected by maritime authorities every time a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment not only better attention and stricter procedures to curb the pollution we produce, but also the realization that if we fail to do so, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another ten years to control illegal marine parties more effectively and efficiently.
President, the review of the Rovillas Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, especially the peripheral countries who feel they are the victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the issue of external costs of road transport, attributing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles that inspire the proposal - the polluter pays and the user pays - are reasonable, the proposed solution is not, in any way, reasonable, as it will be discriminatory for a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, or rather, that was not the goal, has turned out to be the end.

This proposal, ladies and gentlemen, is untimely and far from achieving the expected goals of sustainable transport, it would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European enterprises that employ thousands of people.

people in the European Union who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their final consumer, a consumer who will see their products become more expensive due to the application of these taxes.
Ladies and gentlemen, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally friendly transportation system, bypassing the road, because currently it is the only way to get everywhere.
Modal shift remains a dream, far from being a reality.
European networks, sea highways, and border connections are still, in some cases, projects rather than reality.
Ladies and gentlemen, when the titanic of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to keep playing, much less for joy.

Mr President, on 15 July 2008, the European Commission adopted a communication addressed to the Council and Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13, pending the Parliament's opinion on the matter.
Let us recall that as early as the seventh meeting of the Mexico-European Union Parliamentary Committee, held at the end of October last year, we said that a
The Strategic Association between Mexico and the European Union is a necessary boost to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
we note the good state of relations between both parties and the positive assessment of the current global agreement.

We insist on the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperative matters, especially in the face of new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is sweeping across our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of governance, a commitment to gender equality, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
As a result, we will support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union-Mexico Strategic Association, which will be submitted to Parliament this very morning.
I would like, with regard to the report on microcredit, to congratulate all the rapporteurs, because they have done a great job.
has undoubtedly improved the Commission's initiative.
I understand that the recommendations set out here will allow us to establish a foundation for developing a genuine framework in the European Union for the microcredit sector, a sector
I believe it has been a success in many developing countries, even in some European ones, both as a mechanism for economic activity and as a tool for improving social inclusion and job creation.

But it had not been transferred to the sector or the community context. And I believe that this is an opportunity to do so, especially starting from the economic and financial context in which we are.
It is a priority, in this sense, to strengthen the initiatives being advanced here, but more progress needs to be made.
The funds available for this microcredit support structure need to be increased.
We need to facilitate availability for people and businesses that do not have access to loans, and in that regard, I would like to highlight, Madam President, the example of
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate such access and which has been included in the report.
And I end up thinking that, without a doubt, this will lay the foundations for us to create a harmonious framework in the European context that will boost the microcredit sector.

Madam President, taking advantage of the fact that we are discussing the budget, I understand that we must prepare ourselves for the negotiation next year of the continuation of aid to coal, an essential indigenous energy source.
And I say this in advance, because improperly, some high-ranking official, confusing public opinion, allowed themselves to express an opposing view, leaking it to an economic publication.
None of that.
Support for coal in my country must continue after 2012, and I want this to be recorded in the minutes.
Limit yourselves, gentlemen officials, to complying with the current plan and then, starting in 2012, with the instrument that we will begin to negotiate with the sector next year.
Mr President, Commissioner, this question, as Mr Bokland has explained, is very timely given the Diplomatic Conference on the Ship Recycling Convention to be held in May.
That is why I want to congratulate Mr Bloan not only for the question but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of fighting against the bad practices and methods that have been used to shame ships and, therefore, we support Mr. Brokland's motion for a resolution. But there are some points that concern us.
The first is paragraph 3, which he also pointed out, which says that ships as a whole should be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment on this point because there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted, but it should be the future international agreement on ship dismantling that defines the details of its application.
The proposed Resolution also calls for a funding mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

We think it is really a bit premature to talk about mandatory contributions at this point when the IWO has not yet decided on the system to be adopted for this funding. And I don't think the European Commission has a clear answer on this issue either.
Finally, point 15 urges the Commission to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
We do not believe it is the Commission's competence to decide this, which should also be decided in an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure consistency between the future Convention on the recycling of ships G and the Basel Convention on the control of transboundary movements of hazardous wastes and their disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention, but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we have a great deal of agreement regarding this programme, and congratulate all of us, because in times of economic crisis, it is essential to maintain a programme like this with clear positive social effects.

Although we are dealing with a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, in these times of economic uncertainty, we in Brussels and Strasbourg are not exclusively concerned or

We are concerned about a recovery of the financial system, but we are fully aware that social policies, especially those that support those who need it most, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy. Here we agree with the Commission, not only because European agriculture has a strong social character, but also because it is an instrument that works, because it is needed now more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

In the Socialist group, like the rapporteur, we are opposed to this program being cofinanced between the European Union and the Member States, as this would lead to discrimination between countries based on their wealth, and could result in the program not being implemented in the most needy countries.

it is understood that now, when the most need for aid is felt, they want to save community money in the most social aspect of the CAP, especially considering that there are budget surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full Community funding is essential for us.
we need to ensure that this program reaches all countries, especially the most needy ones
forty-three million potential beneficiaries of this program demand a greater effort from us and, in no case, should we cut back on budgetary spending.
Austerity yes, but not for the poorest.
And it is precisely to ensure that it reaches the citizen of all Member States that the programme must cover the entire journey of the food distributed.

Therefore, the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, has submitted an amendment so that all expenses derived from distribution, including those of transportation, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
we also agree with the rapporteur that food should preferably be Community-produced and of high quality.
the stance is consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programmes that we recently discussed in this chamber, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
that's all and thank you very much
we hope that the commission will take account of this parliament's position when the vote is taken and, above all, that the plan will be implemented in the European Union as soon as possible
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions on our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The thawing of large areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making it necessary to establish new global regulations to protect the Arctic, similar to those already in place for the Antarctic, while taking into account the differences that have already been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty is needed among all the parties involved, including undoubtedly the European Union, to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable nature of human activities of all kinds, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation to manage common problems.

In these times of difficulty and uncertainty, we must raise that spirit and that harmony to higher levels to prevent the states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geostrategic conflicts, forgetting what should be the common goal: the preservation of a great shared heritage.
Mr President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I agree with most of the speakers.
This is a good directive, an excellent directive, aimed at protecting interpreters.
When people talk about seeking a smarter model for doing business, what they're really talking about is putting an end to intellectual property.
Because you can only do business if there is an established right.
You already have an established right at the national level.
The Commission, under Mr. Macrivy's division, has taken a bold initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe the House should approve the compromise we have.
achieved in the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur Mr Crowley and the various shadow rapporteurs such as Mrs McGull and Mr Tubón
I think it is a magnificent Directive, one that will boost the creation of intellectual property.
And, in addition, the Directive includes a few recommendations regarding the continuation of the work.
I believe that approval by this House will reshape things and I hope that the Council will align the lines of the Commission and Parliament's Council, so that in the next legislative term the

The Commission should continue along this path, make proposals to Parliament, and move forward in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a great institution based on a common culture.

Mr President, the information you give me is correct, but the impression we European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens have is that we have a very dangerous loophole in Community law.
At the moment, as tax requirements are being reinforced in each of the member states, mobility is almost impossible.
And when we asked the Commission, the reason for the pragmatic approach is that the Commission never finds support in the Council.

It's a sort of vicious circle where the Commission refers us to the Council and the Council refers us back to the Commission. But in the meantime, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we want to build don't have the opportunity to live in different countries or establish relationships because of the heavy tax burden that can result from the lack of tax harmonization.
Can the Council do something to help us break out of this vicious circle?

Madam President, for once I am glad that the headline that Mr Tajani has come is not true, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of Parliament and a Member of the European Parliament.
And as a Member of the European Parliament, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European parliamentarians have with regard to the application of Community law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to pick on the Commission. I think we are asking the Commission an impossible task, because all Community law and all the application of Community law is based on indirect application.

That is, the Commission has only a few officials at headquarters where some complaints come in and they have some possibilities for action. But, at the moment, there is also a trend to limit budgetary powers, so the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, the entire application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges and national officials.
And here, in this respect, I don't think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we need to do is help the Commission, and I believe that in Mrs Frazoni's report, there are some points that can be useful in achieving this application.
I am referring to those relating to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments and the action of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, on a mission led by my colleague and fellow group member, Mariaán, who is present here, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra and to be present in this court and to be aware of the immense work that this court was carrying out not only for Sierra Leone but for all of humanity.
the special court in sierra leone, as you have already been told here, has certainly set a precedent

A precedent, because, as the Resolution rightly points out, it is the first international tribunal financed by voluntary contributions, it is the first tribunal to be established in the country where the alleged crimes took place, and it is also the first tribunal, as has already been noted, in which a former prime minister has been tried.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but also because it serves as a reference for other tribunals that have been established in its wake, such as those in Rwanda, the former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, and Lebanon, we consider it essential that this Resolution be approved, on which we have been working together with the tribunal for several months now.
Two years ago we passed a resolution to support its funding two years ago the court was going through a difficult period in which it was running out of
money and did not have enough support, we must also thank the European Commission for coming to the financial support of this tribunal

Now we are asking for two things above all: first, that the convicted individuals serve their sentences. At stake is not just the functioning of the Tribunal, which ends next year, but the legacy that this Tribunal will leave us. And secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by increased funding.
Ultimately, the Sierra Leone War Crimes Tribunal is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have tried war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and it is a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, upon entering the courthouse, we saw a slogan written that said "Without justice, there is no peace."
precisely for that reason we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this tribunal remains permanent in history

I was a minute late. Before I begin, I want to respond to the Commissioner, who knows about my friendship and affection for her, and indeed, my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.

I don't even want Mrs. Cúva to answer me, because obviously she is not the one who has the data. But all the data she has given me is in line with what we knew and with what the Ombudsman also knows and doesn't tell us if, indeed

Mr. President, I believe that the proposed regulations that you have submitted to the committee are important and necessary, and on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that, from the

The European Parliament insisted on the principles that have been emphasized by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, both Mr. Viesca and Mr. Deré, and that is the principle of community competence.
This is an issue of Community competence in which, for practical reasons, it is advisable to maintain certain powers of the States, but, as Mr Barrot said, limited in terms of scope and time.
Community competence is unavailable and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor Parliament have the authority to renounce these community competences.

That being said, this is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, which I think will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the approval of this package of measures at first reading.

But I also hope that, on the part of the Commission, in the future and starting from this, we can make progress in developing a genuine European private law that is increasingly necessary — as Mr. Sogor highlighted, for example, in the last speech.
We are talking about the problems that directly affect people and to the extent that we are able to solve these problems, people will realize that the European Union has a role to play.

In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr de Breya, Mrs de Breya, and thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this issue.

Madam President, Commissioner, I signed this resolution and asked to speak on this issue because I witnessed what was called an expulsion, but which in reality was the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrero.

And furthermore, I was able to confirm that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of adversaries, threats, disregard for human dignity, and the trivial use of justice are all common practices in Venezuela, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and led to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his that are cited in the Resolution and others that are not cited.
Such is the case of Ligio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger, and also because he voted for a mayor who was not part of the Chavista regime.
Eligio studied thanks to the help of others, and specifically Citibank, and managed to found his own business, Banco de Caracas. Moreover, he later lived a normal life helping those most in need.
Today, however, he is imprisoned in a Caracas jail, illegally, two years after being detained without any valid charges.
Their only crime is being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nison Moreno, a student leader at the University of Los Andes, who was elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2013 elections to the current position of Minister of the Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is charged with manslaughter, in a state of frustration, violent lascivious acts, and all of this despite having been exonerated from previous accusations.

Situations like yours are everyday life in this country where the persecution of opponents, with the intention of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent, have become part of daily life.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am sure that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be deposed at the polls.
Madam President, Commissioner, indeed, it is undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but, despite all the progress, the south of the Union is burning and burning more and more.
That is why the Resolution that we approve in this Parliament cannot be just another Resolution that serves to highlight the great concern that we feel for the misfortunes of others.
Wildfires occur for one reason or another, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in some states or autonomous communities, the fact is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to deploy all the resources at its disposal, which are not few.
Neither the victims, nor the damage suffered, nor the need for reforestation understand bureaucracy, nor can they understand budget shortfalls.

We must prioritize and we must act. And acting means, in this case, modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them and coordinating preventive policies in an optimal manner, demanding accountability when necessary.

In case, responsibilities to the States that lack them. But assuming that this is not a problem of some States in southern Europe and that climate change does not only affect some States. It affects everyone and is a common cause.
That is why one of the main tasks facing this Parliament in the near future must be to ensure that the European Union achieves clear commitments at the upcoming Copenhagen Summit.

We need to take drastic measures to minimize greenhouse gas emissions, because, obviously, they are at the root of the fires, of their causes, and these, in turn, are at the root of more climate change.
Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, without a doubt.
But for the Commission's challenge to be met, Commissioner, you really do want to prevent the south of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr President, thank you very much for giving me the floor. I am addressing Mr Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and respect for a long time, since you were a ruler in a country that is very close to us and very dear to us, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have absolutely taken me by surprise now.

Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the Community budget, it must be said very loudly and very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency should be. And in past decades it has been seen that without the CAP, food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot therefore be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to run his business, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that there should be a change of direction for the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, in addition to reestablishing a policy of agricultural market management that provides greater price stability, which would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships between the different agents in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union regulations on the environment.
environment, food safety and animal welfare, because Community producers have to compete with products from third countries where much lower standards are applied for imported products.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to light, will be an effective instrument for combating these crimes.

I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen from the Spanish Presidency, so that this order provides victims with special protection measures that are effective throughout the territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society will provide a real and concrete response to this extremely serious problem of human trafficking, and that we will not just stop at empty words.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Counter-Revolution, which had such an impact and inspired so much hope among the peoples of the world, especially among the most brilliant international youth.
What characterizes, however, at this moment, the dictatorship of the Castro brothers is the impiety towards political and prisoners of conscience, the impiety against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco's treatment of political prisoners, whom he also considered common, and his same obsessive contempt for exiles.
Castro ends up as a tyrant, and all enemies of freedom do when they entrench themselves in power.
But we must save lives and show solidarity with those who are struggling and suffering.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who suppress freedoms.

Let us never again allow a person who was fighting for their rights and those of everyone else to die in a Cuban prison or any other place, without our voices rising up strong and firm to demand their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old black bricklayer, who only asked for improved prison conditions, died after six days of hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And during those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, abandoned by his jailers, amidst, it must be remembered, a thick silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

This week, National Women's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union, saying that violence against women can indeed be ended.

Today we are talking about violence in Mexico, and it seems normal to me to acknowledge that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the military or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, so far the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, which is why it is correct to speak of an almost absolute impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican Government to combat femicides, a harsh but accurate term, when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
For example, in the State of Mexico, in the last four years, only 11 of the criminals who murdered nearly seven women were convicted.
At the same time, it seems that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to 21 years in prison and even

As I was unable to do so last March 11, International Day of the Victims of Terrorism, I would like today from this Parliament to pay them a well-deserved tribute, recognizing the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to start working on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the great forgotten ones and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their executioners.
It is high time that these European institutions recognized the dignity of the victims of terrorism and helped them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

That will honor all those who make it possible and that the first article is that support for the victims of terrorism is the recognition of the right to justice and that no government will ever pay a political price.

There is a call to all those who can defend the victims, so that they never forget that true peace is born from justice, and that is the only one that, from Europe and from anywhere in the world, we who believe in it must defend.

it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to prohibit them outright.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency, and communication of the safety of medicinal products once they are on the market, especially with regard to their risk profiles and the adverse reactions they may produce.

It is worth noting the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency regarding safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.

The solution reached for the acute surveillance notification of suspected adverse reactions is very important, both for the Member States and for those responsible for the marketing of the medicinal products.

Eurovigilance will be the sole source of information, but the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected to have occurred will be informed simultaneously. And this is very important.
It is also worth noting the opportunity it provides consumers to report any adverse reactions, and in this regard, the Agency's creation and management of a portal.
The European Medicines Safety Portal, which in turn links to the portals of each Member State, will help improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.

This Directive and Regulation will contribute significantly to this by improving not only the current procedures, but also the coordination of actions between the different Member States.

Mr President, Commissioner, the Directive adopted in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been governing safety in toys.
It is a big step in the right direction, because it shows us the way forward, but it is not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the surveillance mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic, SMR, fragrances, and other hazardous substances, such as HPA compounds.
The rules to be followed need to be clearer about the warning regarding the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of children's behavior.
We need to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advances supported by solid studies and be more rigorous in market surveillance and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation between member states and rely on the joint work of customs to control the route of imported toys.

Madam President, in January 2012, four Spanish egg producers could disappear, accounting for around 30% of the total in my country, resulting in the loss of 300,000 tons of egg production.

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those two million tons, and we would only manage to have them covered by imports from third countries whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union if we do not act with great intelligence.
This 1999 Directive, which requires an increase in the space available in cages for laying hens, demands that we act with intelligence and a forward-thinking approach, because otherwise
We will only manage to weaken European production and give extra commercial opportunities to third countries where the space is infinitely worse than the current one we have in the European Union.

It is a Directive that requires a huge effort from European producers. So in Spain we can understand that the cost rises to about 600 million euros, but we must also remember that it has an economic impact that extends to the food industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask for the support of the honourable Members for the amendment by the Popular Group to the second paragraph, which calls for a solution to be sought, at least for the responsible industrial holdings that are in the process of transforming their holdings and will have almost completed this by January 2012.

We must support them in transforming these facilities and give them time to complete this process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to the farms and preventing a sudden shortage in the community market, which would consequently increase prices for consumers.
It is about respecting the directive to give the egg and egg product industry a chance, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Mr President, today is also European Day against Sexual Violence.
Ladies and gentlemen, the data is alarming. The World Health Organization estimates that more than 300 million people contract a sexually transmitted disease involuntarily each year.

In Europe, as the European Forum for Equal Health warns, the increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers is worrying due to an excessive lack of education and information among our young people.

Moreover, as the Commission points out, there are different and diverse inequalities in Europe regarding access to sexual health services, depending on the states and within them, depending on the income level of citizens.
A European strategy is needed to combat all of this.
Only five member states have plans in this regard, but in all of them, the number of unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted disease infections, and also the number of abortions has been reduced.
A common strategy that focuses on prevention in the educational field, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and facilitates accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A cross-cutting and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the right of every citizen to sexual health under the safest and healthiest conditions.

Madam President, it has already been said that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is still normative that in the OECD countries, the highest levels of equity in citizens' income are found in pensions, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost 20% of their value in 2008 alone, and that they are still far from the required solvency levels today.

All this demonstrates that, at a time of unprecedented reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be addressed in a cross-cutting manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on birth rates or work-life balance.

Equally ambitious policies for access to and permanence in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration, which also guarantee, from a demographic point of view, the sustainability of our pensions.

Mr President, Commissioner, we are at a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on territorial ones.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories so that their citizens can make the most of their territorial distinctiveness.
But in order to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that are facing the same challenges and problems.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union Strategy for the Atlantic region, a common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states in the region, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 Strategy and the European Union's policies for the period after 2013, especially with regional policy and maritime policy.
But, ladies and gentlemen, above all, it is necessary that this strategy be based on renewed multi-level governance, based on closer participation of public authorities.
regional and local authorities, Member States, the European Union and private sector stakeholders and civil society organisations, including interregional organisations and networks.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Roviñeta, which was conceived as a source of funding for infrastructure, will ultimately only allocate 15% to the funding of European networks, and not in a mandatory manner.

This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much more harsh in a situation of economic crisis.

If we want to regain the confidence of the markets and in the markets, we must carry out a thorough reform of the audits so that they represent a genuine added value and not just a legal burden.
The big accounting firms use audit services as a calling card for future clients.
Once they are familiar with the company, they offer more comprehensive complementary services with which to compensate for the often low prices of the strict audit.
We have a problem of price distortion in the sector.

These complementary services already account for almost 50% of the billing, so the big auditors don't want to lose the audit services, but not because of the audit itself, rather to maintain and increase the complementary services.
The second major obstacle to free competition in the sector is the oligopoly of the four major players that dominate European markets by more than 90%.
As such oligopolies, they control prices and establish barriers to entry for new competitors, using intangibles such as international brand image.

It is true that this brand image may be based on dietary advantages, but it does not always imply greater efficiency due to the diversity of legislation in the accounting states that may require particular treatment in each member state.
I share the objectives of the Green Paper, the independence and the regulation of the sector, and the means to be used, such as rotation and joint audits.
Tendering, reinforcement of professional skepticism, prevalence of substances over forms, separation of audit services from non-audit services.
I have tried to incorporate them into my report to the extent that the parliamentary majorities and the modest scope of the report have allowed.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is only a small step towards achieving new legislation that will address the issues in the field of audits that have led us to this terrible economic crisis.

The same request was included in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.

This, this fraud, is fixed by amending the implementing regulation of the Common Organisation of the Market in Agricultural Products, because, Commissioner, aligning the code in January does not fix the problem.

For several years now, I have been advocating within the Popular Party for the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union equips itself with the necessary instruments to ensure compliance with the current agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States that must ensure control of imports.

However, what the Commission tells us is that the entry price system is in effect, and that it prevents national customs authorities from properly tracing the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

We need to amend the Regulation implementing the CMO for agricultural products, and we will have solved part of the problem, because otherwise, the legal loophole in European legislation prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I would like to pay tribute today to all the women who, despite the significant progress we have made since that March of 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that women's equality is still far from being achieved.
Today women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in the rural world whose work is ignored.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

This year alone, there has already been an excessive number of women murdered, not to mention the serious threats made by those who believe they have the right to exercise physical or psychological violence against them.
And the time to say goodbye and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order and to the Victims' Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind you, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle to women's progression, and I believe it is a trend that needs to change.
I want to send a message of hope and with many women, with the help of more and more men, we have to move forward on the path of equality, of opportunities, rights and also of duties.
We have come a long way but there is still much to be done.
I have to admit that I don't believe deeply and absolutely in quotas, but I have to tell you that something has to be done and I agree.

I have worked with many of my colleagues and, of course, with Mrs. Reding, to open up this debate and to move forward on this path so that women can regain the place they deserve, and you can count on my help in this endeavor.

Mr. President, at a time of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health and in which, as in the case of the community where I live, research centers like the Prince Felipe Center, specialized in diabetes, are left without funding, this Resolution is more timely than ever, it is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a Council recommendation that tells the States that they have to increase research, including with stem cells, that they have to coordinate their results to optimize them, that they have to establish programs for healthy eating habits and lifestyle.

In short, we must prioritize people's health above all else, and in this case, research, coordinate, and implement national programs coordinated by the Commission and demand results. Addressing diabetes is about ensuring the quality of life of Europeans and guaranteeing their very lives.

If we allocate more money to this, some will take a little longer to collect, but those who are currently having problems will certainly have a better quality of life, and we, as States, as Council, and as Commission, will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to ensure the health of our citizens.
Mr President, of the many issues that this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions trading market, a market that was certainly born with defects.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. That is, the price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, the increase in emissions is being encouraged. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and what is worse...
The funding of important projects, such as those related to energy efficiency or carbon storage plants, will be jeopardized.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and Parliament, to swear to uphold it.

The European social model that we are so proud of is not only based on our pension, education, and healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balance between employers and employees within companies.

The labor reform that the Spanish government has approved without dialogue and without consensus breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 strategy, both in terms of job creation and in terms of job quality.
Labour reform alone does not create jobs; economic growth does.
What a labor law does define, however, are the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave them.
And with this reform, 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, where they can be fired due to a decrease in company revenue or
they can unilaterally modify their schedules, what is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

That is why this reform, which attacks the European social model and bets on the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to workers' conditions, deserves a general strike like the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

We are living through a major controversy that is fundamentally based on the concepts of austerity and growth.
If you listen to the noise that is being created, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these days.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the pact that is precisely called the Stability and Growth Pact has been in effect since 1997.

That is why a large part of the policies carried out by European institutions, such as those on regional cohesion and research, are growth-oriented policies that aim to promote the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I am addressing the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the most chance of being heard, we will not have any complexes when it comes to engaging in that debate, which we can face with our heads held high.

Madam President, allow me first of all to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for their help on this report, which has made it much stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, a key factor in overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.

Over these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that generate dynamism.
And trust, transparency, a basic principle of democracy and good governance, to which Commissioner Bernier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly of vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it difficult to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This obliges us to address the problem of vulnerability from a cross-cutting analysis that takes into account the different needs, capacities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
While it is an ambitious proposal, it is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive or of the options available or of their lack of knowledge of the existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

This is why, in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislation to ensure adequate protection.

It goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has been shown to be higher and where the highest number of consumer complaints are recorded. The financial sector, whose complexity means that, in theory, any consumer could become vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is urged to redouble its efforts to provide comprehensible, truthful information, with clear explanations and straightforward language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector in relation to advertising

foods high in fat, salt and sugar and children and young people who are most susceptible to advertising for these foods, the transport sector, which often still struggles when vulnerable people travel. The energy and telecommunications sector

where the lack of transparency causes, in some cases, an added difficulty for consumers, for example, in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, in access to justice, where consumers may find it difficult to access the mechanisms.
existing.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are urged - and allow me to sound a warning note to the Spanish Minister for Justice, Mr Gallardón - not to backtrack on rights.
And in line with the spirit of these challenging times, let us use intelligence and good governance to promote alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.
Finally, it should be noted that any one of us can become a vulnerable consumer. Thank you very much and I would like to thank everyone for their help in strengthening this report.

Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have continually denounced female genital mutilation.
It is that silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls around the world suffer from, seven million, I repeat, seven million.

An unbearable figure for anyone who takes the time to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which are hidden under the guise of psychological, health, and religious reasons, all of which are false.

The truth is that female genital mutilation, preferably performed on girls as young as a few months old or even a year, can lead to death due to hemorrhagic shock and, in the best-case scenario, cause severe psychological trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls, and this treatment of girls as less than human also exists in Europe.
To do this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available to our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out, so that the law in Europe speaks with a single voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop, because we owe it to the seven million women who have been mutilated.

Madam President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to highlight the excellent work of Mrs Macagan, the rapporteur, and also of the other shadow rapporteurs, for having reached this agreement.
It was agreed at first reading, which was very important, since the regulations we had approved in 2010 were coming into force and needed to be revised.
Not because it was the legislation, the legislation was very good, but as has been said, the recent events that everyone knows about occurred and demonstrated that there was a certain
It was necessary to correct the issue so that it would not happen again, and specific points of vigilance and security of the medications once they were commercialized had to be reinforced.
Therefore, from now on, as stated, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicinal product who do not renew, withdraw or request withdrawal or suspend the authorization will have
obligation to declare the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or suspension of a medicinal product's authorization.
This is a major achievement in the name of transparency and will prevent the marketing authorization holder from attempting to hide the true reasons for their decision.
Furthermore, in the event that any of these actions is carried out in a third country, all the Member States concerned where this medicinal product is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and security without, however, overburdening the European Medicines Agency and the national agencies too much.

The second important change that has been achieved is that all authorized products that are subject to post-authorization safety studies are automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Lastly, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, which is why this plenary must approve this proposal.

When people in my country ask me what I do in Europe, I can proudly say that I am legislating in favor of the victims.

Mr President, Mr Turmes has done an admirable job because to push through a regulation like this required the courage of this rapporteur, who has managed to overcome the many and skilfully laid obstacles.
It has been worth it, because efficiency in the use of energy and its saving are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should welcome important measures such as the requirement for public buildings to be renovated, the imposition of an accumulated energy savings percentage on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits for large private companies.
However, the work of Turmes and the other rapporteurs will be for nothing if it is not accompanied by decisive action from the Member States.
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives by the regions, municipalities, and European citizens.
I am interested in highlighting the participation of the latter.

The rapporteur's work, Mr President, is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here in this context that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can see.
We forget what Puffendorf already taught us: that general laws should be few and their meaning must be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who promulgate it must use all the clarity that is possible.
Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it generates a malicious network where traps lurk and arbitrariness takes hold.
We deal with very complex issues in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the public in a comprehensible and accessible way.
It is common for even the same legal professionals, judges, and lawyers to become desperate when faced with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the legislator's courtesy and a way of demonstrating their respect for the citizen.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an old principle that has passed from the legal sphere to the political one, and that is pacta sunt servanda, that is, agreements are meant to be kept.
By this I mean the important measures adopted by the European Council in June to resolve the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and they have welcomed decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irreversibly.
The European Council meeting last week contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions on progress towards a banking union are satisfactory.
The agreement on the implementation of the banking supervisor is also positive. Finally, it is appropriate that the implementation be entrusted to the Ministers of Economy of Luozona.
But it will allow you to make a critical judgment of the biased interpretations that have been made unilaterally of it.

It is not acceptable, ladies and gentlemen, to make private interpretations that may distort the mandate given to the Ministers of Economy, nor do we approve of presenting as agreements matters that were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism, which must cover all financial entities.
A common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are also needed.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are indisputable: increased competition, a greater range of products and services, and...
services, creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers and greater protection, still not enough and we cannot become complacent.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully taking advantage of the benefits of the single market.
A year and a half ago, we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and reinforce citizens' confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as the Commission acknowledged in last week's communication.

Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis obliges us to be ambitious, to go much further and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr President, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the rest of the colleagues who have worked on this reform so well.

The financial crisis has been exacerbated by the existence of complex and strange negotiable securities that are linked to derivative instruments and negotiations outside of official markets, all with the aim of achieving high returns at great speed.
It is necessary to attract financial operations to a transparent market to ensure the proper formation of prices and competition among tradable products.
But above all, it is essential that the information provided is understandable to investors, who must have full knowledge to give free consent to the risks they are taking on.
Transparency is of no use as a great flash of light if the complexity in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.

The figures speak for themselves, processor.
The decline in sales in the European market, combined with business strategy, generally leads to outsourcing and corporate restructuring.
There is an overcapacity crisis currently affecting ten assembly plants and potentially 6,000 workers.
Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision. Generally, a short-term vision prevails in which the main element is to gain competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I must say that on the same day that Ford announced the suspension of the Gen plant, the Valencia Ford company was informed that its production was going to be moved to Germany in the same corporate announcement.

Mr President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalisation of our common security and defence policy.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a clear European dimension, in the face of minority and Eurosceptic sectors that also prevail in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Danjian, whom I would like to thank for his spirit of consensus-seeking during its preparation, contains important contributions from the Social Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible revision of the European Defence Strategy.
We have also pointed out that a strong common security and defense policy is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another challenge that is taking on significant dimensions for our global security.
It is about cybersecurity and cyber defense, reports that we also discussed today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European Cybersecurity Strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis in which member states are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is precisely when European projects are most necessary.
That is why it is more important than ever to reinforce the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being strongly contested today.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defense and do so with President Vor Rapuy's project for the December 2013 Council.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again, the defence of the general interests upheld by the Commission and Parliament clashes with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Given the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable not to reach a balance.
The relevance of the next financial framework is unquestionable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our judgment, unacceptable.
A cut of 75 billion euros on the already inevitably meager proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And not only that, the new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies means crossing the red line that Spain indicated from the start of the negotiations.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is no longer time to argue about a supposed dichotomy between authority and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices for deficit correction.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
And with this budget, you're not getting anywhere. Rather, it's a weight on the waterline.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with much fewer resources, and especially not if what there is is distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that simply means the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity. And this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, who should be thanked for their efforts in pointing out a different route.

And at this point, in the need for Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a strong statement the other day in Cádiz interpreting the Treaties for a supposed federalist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State separates as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself will not affect it.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this can be taken into account and that this safe and consistent doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the guarantee of all.
